children.subject: <md>CS 285 doesn't require an A+ in 189 (only requires that you've taken it)</md>

<md>For my knowledge, most graduate CS courses in AI have guaranteed enrollment only for PhD students. (There are even some seminars that require a screening of even PhD students). Even for 5th year masters, you may go through a screen potentially like advanced undergraduates. The good news is that usually in a 5th year masters, you have some research experience and some professor vouching for you, so that can get you through the door sometimes. All in all, depends on enrollment and professor policy. </md>

history.content:
I'm interested in a 5th year MS in the fields of robotics/control, and I need a draft course plan to apply. I'm currently taking CS 188 and CS 189, among others, and enjoying the content.

1. What are the chances of CS 285 (Deep RL) being offered in the fall? Seems to be offered consistently in the Fall for the last few years, but there doesn't appear to be a draft course schedule out for 2022-2023.

2. What are the chances of CS 287 (Advanced Robotics) being offered in the fall? Seems to be inconsistent, with the last offering in Fall 2019(?).

3. Are the exclusionary enrollment policies likely to prevent me from taking these courses even if they are offered? CS 287 is notorious for requiring 9 A+ grades or 3 A+ in 188/189/182/126/127, including for 5th yr students (I took 127 PNP and 182 is not guaranteed to be offered this Spring...), and it looks like 285 similarly asks for your grade in CS189. Like most students, I do not expect to get an A+ in CS 189.

While I could probably get this info from emailing professors, figured someone might already know / also benefit from knowing.
history.subject: CS 285 and 287 future offerings and enrollment
